thread.title: Samsung's Earnings Shock: High Stakes for Roh Tae-moon and the Galaxy S25
thread.title_full: Samsung's Earnings Shock: High Stakes for Roh Tae-moon and the Galaxy S25

author: Lee Gwang-young
title: Samsung's Earnings Shock: High Stakes for Roh Tae-moon and the Galaxy S25
text:
Samsung Electronics posted weaker-than-expected earnings for the fourth quarter of 2024, impacted by a slowdown in its semiconductor business and weaker performance in its Mobile Experience (MX) division, including underwhelming sales of foldable phones. As pressure mounts, MX chief Roh Tae-moon is pinning hopes on the upcoming Galaxy S25 series to reverse the trend.
Samsung announced on January 8 that its Q4 operating profit rose 130.5% year-on-year to KRW 6.5 trillion ($5.4 billion), but fell short of market expectations of over KRW 7 trillion. The figure also marked a 29.2% decline from Q3 2024.
The MX division, a key profit driver, is estimated to have generated slightly over KRW 2 trillion in operating profit for Q4, reflecting sluggish demand and intensifying competition. This compares to the KRW 13 trillion in full-year operating profit the division achieved in 2023, which helped offset semiconductor losses of KRW 14.9 trillion. However, with foldable phone sales slowing in 2024, the MX division is projected to barely exceed KRW 10 trillion in annual operating profit, underscoring the importance of the Galaxy S25 launch.
Samsung will unveil the Galaxy S25 series on January 22 in San Jose, California, introducing advanced features such as an upgraded Bixby virtual assistant powered by a large language model (LLM). The new Bixby is expected to deliver conversational capabilities similar to OpenAI's ChatGPT or Google’s Gemini.
The Galaxy S25 Ultra will feature a new design with rounded corners, aligning its look with the Galaxy S25 and S25 Plus, according to German tech outlet WinFuture. Additionally, Android OS expert Mishaal Rahman reports that the series will support next-generation Qi2 wireless charging, offering improved efficiency and up to 15W power delivery using a magnetic-based system.
All Galaxy S25 models will use Qualcomm’s Snapdragon 8 Elite processor, abandoning Samsung’s in-house Exynos chips. This shift is expected to slightly raise prices compared to the previous generation.
Speculation is also mounting about a new "Slim" model, which could debut as the thinnest S series smartphone ever. Hints from Samsung’s teaser video for the Unpacked event have fueled such rumors, with the device potentially launching later this year.
Samsung is also integrating subscription services into its Galaxy lineup. At CES 2025, Samsung DX head Han Jong-hee confirmed plans to introduce subscription options for Galaxy smartphones starting in February, including the S25 series. "We aim to provide a wider range of choices with a differentiated approach," Han said.
The Galaxy S25 series marks a pivotal moment for Samsung as it seeks to reclaim momentum amid mounting competition in the smartphone market.
